awd_titl_txt: Climatological, Composite, and Case Study Analyses Linking Rossby Wave Breaking to Potential Vorticity Streamer and Cutoff Cyclone Formation in the Subtropical North Atlantic Basin
awd_abstract_narration:
Extreme weather events, although having a low probability of occurrence, can exert very high adverse socioeconomic impacts.  The goal of the funded research is to investigate the climatology, seasonality, and their interactions with background flows of a variety of extreme weather events that impact parts of the United States, Central America, and the Western Caribbean. Candidate extreme weather events to be investigated include heavy, flood-producing rainstorms during the cooler half of the year and tropical disturbances that can bring flooding rains, damaging winds, and devastating storm surges during the warmer half of the year. These candidate extreme weather events often occur in conjunction with upper tropospheric disturbances known as cutoff cyclones.  Cutoff cyclones that form in higher latitudes can dump chilly air into the subtropics, fueling cold waves initially and big rainstorms subsequently.  Cutoff cyclones that form in lower latitudes can enable warm, moist tropical air to reach midlatitudes, fueling tropical cyclone landfalls and/or exceptionally heavy rainfalls.  A novel aspect of the research is that it is targeted at the interaction of tropical and midlatitude circulations associated with cutoff cyclones.  These cutoff cyclones can govern the timing, occurrence, and location of extreme weather events in the United States, Central America, and western Caribbean. Another innovation of this research project is that historically extreme weather events have been studied in isolation.  This historical approach precludes the possibility of detecting the occurrence of multiple geographically separated but dynamically linked extreme weather events that may be occurring near simultaneously in different parts of the world.  A sure-fire recipe for the occurrence of extreme weather events is the existence of a wavy, high-amplitude, large-scale flow pattern across the Northern Hemisphere that can break down into a series of cutoff cyclones.  A critical science issue is determining the physical causes of flow breakdown that can lead to cutoff cyclone formation.  The research project will use state-of-the-art global gridded datasets to identify the frequency of extreme weather events associated with cutoff cyclones.  Climatological, composite, and case study analyses will be constructed from these gridded datasets to help quantify the physical processes governing the location and occurrence of these extreme weather events.

The broader impacts of the research are substantial, including (1) the education of the next generation of scientists in the field, (2) opportunities to interact with scientists at NOAA's National Hurricane Center to facilitate the transfer of research to operations, and (3) educating meteorologists from Central America and the Caribbean through outreach and training activities to ensure they are current on weather patterns conducive to the occurrence of extreme weather events in their regions.

por.por_cntn:
The research conducted with support from NSF-1656406 supported six graduate students (5 Ph.D. students and 1 M.S. student) and one postdoctoral research associate. The students included Benjamin Moore, now with NOAA-ESRL in Boulder, CO, Philippe Papin, now with NHC in Miami, FL, Alicia Bentley, now with NCEP in College Park, MD, Jason Cordeira (formerly with Plymouth State University and now with CW3E at Scripps), and Heather Archambault (formerly with Citadel and now with Aeolus). This grant has also supported one current Ph.D. student, Alexander Mitchell. These students conducted research on a wide-ranging number of topics. Benjamin Moore examined heavy rain events over the central and eastern U.S. He showed that these vents could be linked to upstream Rossby wave breaking.  Philippe Papin conducted a climatological analysis of potential vorticity streamer formation over the North Atlantic Ocean. He showed that these features could be linked to Rossby wave breaking via an interaction with the North Atlantic jet stream. Alicia Bentley constructed a climatology of extratropical cyclones that resulted in extreme weather events over central and eastern North America. She also examined subtropical cyclones that underwent tropical transition (TT) in the North Atlantic Ocean in which she the importance of upper tropospheric precursors to the TT process. Heather Archambault and Jason Cordeira collaborated with Benjamin Moore and PI Bosart to establish how the interactions of North Pacific tropical, midlatitude, and polar disturbances resulted in a series of linked extreme weather events over North America in October 2007. Current Ph.D. student Alexander is investigating linkages between recurving and transitioning WPAC tropical cyclones, and recurving and weakening East Pacific tropical cyclones, and the occurrence of wildfires and extreme weather events over western North America. Postdoctoral research associate Andrew Winters, also supported on a separate NSF grant to PI. Bosart and Daniel Keyser, developed a real-time North Pacific jet stream phase space diagram that documented large scale NPAC flow regimes conducive to the occurrence of extreme weather events over the CONUS. PI Bosart is extremely gratified by the educational outcomes experienced by these graduate students and postdoctoral research associate.

For a graduate student perspective, the following text was provided by Lance Bosart?s current Ph.D. student, Alexander Mitchell, who was supported on this grant: ?Motivated by my research pertaining to the NSF project, I was able to effectively learn and apply unfamiliar methodologies throughout my coursework, such as, learning how to utilize WRF, testing ensemble sensitivity, applying machine learning, and learning a new programming language (Python). Given my ability to apply my research under multiple perspectives and methodologies founded within various courses, conferences, and workshops, the NSF fostered significant intellectual growth by developing an ability to think philosophically about science within the context of synoptic-dynamic meteorology towards the ongoing area of subseasonal-to-seasonal (S2S) research. The aforementioned forward thinking of S2S research in atmospheric sciences has given me the ability to invest in future research ideas and build a professional network for future collaborators. Largely, my professional network blossomed through having invaluable opportunities and support to present oral talks and posters at both international and national conferences along with invited seminars at federal entities including NCAR and the NHC incorporating all research findings conducted over the project?s reporting periods. My personal growth has been largely attributed to pushing my comfort zone within the scope of conducting research and improving my ability to communicate science to all individuals and a larger audience as a result.?
